div.head: Preface
div.p: The text of the rubrics for 4.6.1 and 4.6.2 is quite similar in all four first-recension (R1) mss., and substantially different from the readings reported in Fr. 4.6.1: "Qui in accusatione episcopi culpabilis inuenitur ad arguendum de cetero non admittatur nisi propriam causam ciuilem solummodo asserere uoluerit" in Aa Bc Fd P and "In ciuili et proprio dumtaxat negotio ad arguendum admittitur, qui in episcopi accusatione culpabilis inuenitur" in Fr. 4.6.2: "Non negatur audientia in propria causa cuius accusatio interdicitur" in Aa Bc Fd P and "Propriam causam agere ualet cui accusare non licet" in Fr.

C.4 q.2-3 d.p.c.3 quotes a cryptic statement, not found in Clavis Canonum, attributed to St. Brice (†.444), a controversial disciple of St. Martin, and his successor as bishop of Tours. "It is remarkable that in his dicta Gratian refers to sources that are not cited in the Decretum. Many biblical citations, for example, are found only in the dicta. They are often tied to important theological reflections ..." (Landau, "Gratian and the Decretum Gratiani", 41.)

There are two marginal glosses in the Admont (Aa) text of C.4 that refer to Burchard's Decretum: "B.xvi. Nemo ſimul ſit." (Burchard 16.15) at 4.4.1, and "B.i. Qͥſqͥs." (Burchard 1.160) at 4.6.1. A rubric in between C.4 and C.5 ("Explicit liber quintus, incipit liber sextus, de episcoporum accusationibus") indicates a non-standard division of the Aa ms. into books.

The order of rubrics in C.4 q.4 is reversed in Bc. The rubric for 4.4.2 ("Quilibet in causa duas personas gerere non valet") appears before 4.4.1, and the rubric for 4.4.1 ("Accusator, testis vel iudex aliquis simul esse non potest") appears before 4.4.2. Bc includes two canons — 4.6.3 and 4.6.4 — not listed in Winroth's appendix and not found in either the Aa or P mss.
The quality of scribal workmanship in the Paris (P) ms. is visibly less professional than that in either the Aa or Bc mss.

div.head: (SC translation of C.4 d.init.)
div.ab: An excommunicate undertook to accuse a bishop. He brought a person under the age of 14 to support his case. [assertio was originally used to mean the defense of a person’s character. In the middle ages the word took on a modern meaning of assertion. It retained its positive meaning—i.e. it was a statement in favor of something. Here, I think it means that the accuser brought the young person in to support his accusation against the bishop.] Prohibited from making the accusation [because he was an excommunicate], he made [introduced, assigned] the adolescent the accuser and himself the witness. [In other words, the excommunicate switched roles with the youth, but the next sentence raises a question about the meaning of se here.] The adolescent began to act as accuser and witness. On the appointed day, the bishop did not agree [minime concurrit] to come before the electors’ [those chosen to be judges] court. He was suspended from communion. Finally, the court having been reconvened, the accuser [I believe this refers to the youth] was found culpable in making the accusation. In the end, he [I believe this person is the original accuser, the excommunicate] proceeded to make his case.
